qas.question: What was a benefit of the use of magnetic pickup cartridge?
In what era could you find good quality recordings and playbacks at home?
What was a unique feature of the Capeart radio phonographs?
How similar were live and recorded versions?

context: Over time, fidelity, dynamic and noise levels improved to the point that it was <a3_0>harder to tell the difference<a3_0/> between a live performance in the studio and the recorded version. This was especially true after the invention of the variable reluctance magnetic pickup cartridge by General Electric in the <a1_0>1940s<a1_0/> when <a0_0>high quality cuts<a0_0/> were played on well-designed audio systems. The Capehart radio/phonographs of the era with <a2_0>large diameter electrodynamic loudspeakers<a2_0/>, though not ideal, demonstrated this quite well with "home recordings" readily available in the music stores for the public to buy.
